bio:
C√©sar Puerta is the technical lead for Twitter for Android, and oversees the application‚Äôs architecture. With a team of 50 developers and a codebase dating from over six years ago, when the cutting-edge version of Android was 2.2 (Froyo), Twitter for Android presents a unique set of challenges when it comes to building a clean, easy to understand codebase.

C√©sar‚Äôs aspirations as technical lead include helping teams collaborate on such large-scale projects, and the migration of shared infrastructure towards design patterns which incorporate modern techniques such as dependency injection and decoupled, modularized, and testable components.

Prior to working on Android, C√©sar worked on localization engineering at Twitter and Electronic Arts in Madrid.

Yash also organizes GDG Philadelphia and volunteers at various local tech groups as an instructor and mentor.

sessions.name: Keynote: Being more than an Android Developer

bio: Yousuf is an engineer at Facebook. He's done client side and server side development in the past, but these days he's trying to figure out how to use technologies like Kotlin to help teams move faster.

sessions.name: How it's made: Jetpack Compose

bio: Zach has been building Android apps at Square for over four years. He gets out of bed in the morning to make doing that easy and fun for others.

sessions.name: Square Workflow: Android and iOS apps composed of state machines defining UI and navigation.

bio: Two years ago, Zach transitioned from the world of mechanical engineering to software engineering and hasn't looked back. While he mostly focuses on android, lately he finds himself exploring the many ways he can leverage Kotlin's multi-platform support to continue broadening his horizons.

sessions.name: How it's made: Jetpack Compose
